abstract.p: From time immemorial, diamond attracted a special attention not only as a precious gemstone but also as an application material due to its unique and unsurpassed properties. Interest in diamond thin film research has enormously increased owing to the fact that most of the diamond properties could be utilized for various applications only when it is in the form of a thin film. At present, diamond thin films are able to serve in applications such as electro-mechanical, electro-chemical, bio-medical, bio-sensing, optical, electronic, and machining. Chemical vapour deposition (CVD) is the standalone technique used for diamond thin film synthesis. The mechanism of which typically involves addition of one carbon atom at a time from carbon containing activated gas phase to an initial template resulting in sp3 carbon atom network (diamond). Depending on the synthesis conditions, diamond thin film can constitute epitaxial, oriented, and polycrystalline (micron- and nano-sized) diamond grains. This article reviews important advances that have taken place in diamond thin film synthesis.

sec.title: 1 INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Diamond thin films have always been fascinating due to their incomparable properties and diverse application potential. At present, diamond thin films are serving in a variety of applications namely electro-mechanical, electro-chemical, bio-medical, bio-sensing, optical, electronic, machining, etc. [1–10]. For the past 50 years, chemical vapour deposition (CVD) has been the standalone route to synthesize diamond thin films. The CVD mechanism involves addition of one carbon atom at a time from a carbon containing activated gas phase (maintained at a lower pressure) to an initial template (a substrate), resulting in a thin film constituted by sp3 carbon atom network (diamond). The CVD route involves gas mixture activation, gas-phase reactions, and the subsequent transfer of diamond-forming gas species onto the substrate surface; further surface reactions lead to the formation of a diamond thin film. Depending on the synthesis conditions such as substrate surface pre-treatment, reaction temperature and pressure, and gas composition, the diamond thin film microstructure can constitute epitaxial, oriented, and polycrystalline (micron- and nano-sized) diamond grains.

Eversole and Kenmore [11] were the first to use low-pressure cyclic pyrolysis process to synthesizediamond. Thereafter, Angus et al. [12] and Derjaguin et al. [13] in their works could synthesize diamond thin films on diamond. However, synthesis of diamond films on non-diamond substrates was possible only after the major breakthrough by Matsumoto et al. [14, 15]. In their work, hydrocarbon and hydrogen gas mixtures were passed over a hotfilament to directly activate the gas phase. Diamond-forming active gas species upon reaching the non-diamond substrate kept several millimetres away from the filament participated in surface reactions, leading to the formation of diamond film on the substrate. Since then, various gas phase activation methods have evolved. At the same time, to enhance diamond thin film growth rates, role of various gas species has been extensively studied. In this review, advances in (a) CVD and non-CVD techniques, (b)diamond nucleation and growth processes, and (c) types of diamond thin films will be discussed. This review article will be concluded with a brief notes on the most recent developments and current directions in diamond thin film research.

sec.title: 2.1.1 Hot filament CVD
sec.p: In hot filament CVD (HFCVD) method [14, 15], a refractory metal (such as tungsten, tantalum, and rhenium) filament is first heated to high temperatures (~2000°C); methane (CH4) and hydrogen (H2) gas mixture typically about 1:99 in volume under low working pressures (~20–40 Torr) is then passed over the hot filament. Pyrolysis of the gas mixture takes place resulting in the generation of diamond-forming active gas species, which upon reaching the substrate surface (maintained at ~700–900°C) kept at a distance of about 8–10 mm from the hot filament form a diamond film. In this synthesis process, the atomic hydrogen produced during pyrolysis selectively etches away graphite that forms along with diamond on the substrate. Thereby, the deposition rates of diamond are typically about 1 µm/h.

A wide variety of carbon gas sources such as methane, propane, ethane, other hydrocarbons, and oxygen-containing hydrocarbons (acetone, ethanol, methanol, etc.) can be easily used for diamond thin film synthesis via HFCVD. Modifications such as application of: (a) a bias voltage to the substrate and filament [16, 17] to induce desorption of the surface hydrogen, which in turn increases the growth rates up to about 10 µm/h, (b) a moderate positive voltage to the substrate and a negative voltage to the filament (or an accessory electrode), resulting in electron bombardment of the substrate such that when the bias voltage is high enough to sustain a discharge, the decomposition of H2 and hydrocarbon is greatly enhanced, leading to a remarkable increase in the diamond growth rates up to about 20 µm/h, and (c)a moderate negative voltage to the substrate and a positive voltage to the filament (or an accessory electrode) such that surface undergoes ion bombardment, resulting in the enhanced nucleation of diamond on non-diamond substrates. The above modifications can be aided with multiple filaments or a filament net, leading to the formation of uniform diamond thin films over large substrate areas.

sec.title: 2.1.2 Microwave plasma-enhanced CVD
sec.p:
In microwave plasma-enhanced CVD (MWCVD), the gas phase activation is done using electrical energy corresponding to the microwave frequency of 2.45 GHz. Upon ignition of the plasma, electrons in it oscillate at microwave frequency and collide with the gas species resulting in high ionization fractions. Under diamond CVD conditions, igniting and sustaining a plasma using electrical energy [18, 19] not only activates the hydrocarbon species but alsoenhances the atomic hydrogen concentration. Typically, the microwaves generated using a magnetron are guided into the reaction chamber filled with the gas mixture maintained at a particular low pressure. The microwave energy is transmitted to the gas mixture, thereby igniting luminous ball-shaped plasma; the size of which can be increased by increasing the microwave power. One edge of the plasma ball will be located typically about 2 cm above an independently heated substrate’s surface. Under suitable conditions of gas pressure, microwave power, gas mixture ratio, gas flowrates of different gases, substrate temperature, etc., the activated diamond-forming species upon reaching the substrate undergo surface reactions and lead to the formation of diamond film on the substrate. A typical MWCVD reactor schematic is shown in Fig. 1. Besides MWCVD, direct current (DC) and radio frequency (RF) plasma CVD methods (Section 2.2) are also possible. Fig. 1
Schematic of a MWCVD reactor used to deposit β-SiC/diamond nanocomposite thin films employing CH4, H2, and TMS gas mixtures. The same reactor can be used to deposit a variety of diamond films employing CH4 and H2 gas mixtures

sec.title: 2.2.1 Oxy-acetylene torch technique
sec.p: In this technique, a welding torch is used to generate acetylene (C2H2) and oxygen (O2) (1:1 ratio) flame that contains active diamond-forming species [20–24]. When the tip of the bright interior region of this flame touches the substrate (maintained at 800–1000°C), diamond film is formed on the substrate. By employing this technique, homo-epitaxial [21], boron-doped [22], and large-area [23, 24] diamond thin films can be synthesized. The advantages of this technique over the other CVD techniques are simplicity, cost-effectiveness of the equipment, high growth rates (up to 50–100 µm/h), and depositions of diamond over large areas and on curved surfaces. On the other hand, in this technique, it is difficult to control the synthesis procedures and consequently, irregularities crop up in both microstructure and composition of the resultant diamond films. Also, during the process of coating large substrate areas, production of thermal gradients over the substrate’s surface is possible, which can result in severe substrate damage.

sec.title: 2.2.2 DC plasma-assisted CVD
sec.p: In DC plasma-assisted CVD (DC PACVD) method [25], reactive gas species are generated by igniting a glow discharge (of typically hydrocarbon and hydrogen mixture) between the substrate and a cathode bydropping a sufficiently high DC bias voltage across them. Area of deposition is limited only by the size of the electrodes and DC power supply. However, this method has a drawback of depositing diamond at very low rates (<0.1 µm/h). With the increase of gas pressure (~150 Torr), DC voltage (~1 kV), and discharge current, growth rates of up to 250 µm/h can be achieved but with a limited area deposition.

A variant of DC PACVD is DC plasma jet method which employs a gas injection nozzle consisting of a cathode rod surrounded by an anode tube [26, 27]. Here, the substrate is placed on a separate water-cooled holder and the plasma is ignited by generating a DC arc discharge between the electrodes. Typically, methane will be mixed with H2/Ar plasma jet at high pressures (~200 Torr). Due to the high temperatures (~5000 K) in the plasma, a large fraction of H2 molecules dissociates and a sufficient supply of diamond-forming active gas species is available. These gas species are transported to the substrate surface within a few hundred microseconds, thereby reducing hydrogen combination reactions. A growth rate of 930 µm/h using the DC plasma jet CVD has been achieved [28]. Boron- or phosphorous-doped diamond films can also be obtained using DC plasma jet CVD [29]. As previously mentioned, diamond films can be synthesized at high growth rates using a hybrid HFCVD plus DC plasma method [17].

sec.title: 2.2.3 RF plasma CVD
sec.p: Here, RF is used to generate plasma using two electrode configurations, namely capacitively coupled parallel plates and induction at atmospheric pressure. RF plasma-assisted CVD utilizes a frequency of 13.56 MHz. RF plasma can be used to deposit diamond on areas larger than those possible using microwave plasmas. However, sputtering and/or ion bombardment at the reaction surface might take place due to RF conditions, resulting in severe defects in the growing diamond film. Polycrystalline [30] and homo-epitaxial [17] diamond films have been synthesized via induction methodology.

sec.title: 2.2.4 Electron cyclotron resonance microwave plasma-assisted CVD
sec.p: In this technique, electron cyclotron resonance (ECR) is achieved in a magnetic field of 875 gauss at the standard microwave frequency of 2.45 GHz (as in MWCVD) [31–33]. This generates high-density plasma (>1 × 1011 cm−3) suitable for diamond growth. Using this technique, uniform diamond films can be synthesized at substrate temperatures as low as 300°C. However, extremely low reaction pressures (~10−4 to 10−2 Torr) limits the diamond growth rate.

sec.title: 2.3 Non-CVD techniques
sec.p: Non-CVD methods based on low-energy [34] and high-energy [35] carbon-ion beams were also developed to synthesize diamond thin films. Physical vapour deposition methods were also employed [36, 37]. Electrolysis of acetates also resulted in the formationof diamond thin films at temperatures as low as75°C [38].

sec.title: 3.1 Nucleation
sec.p: Diamond nuclei are the smallest stable diamond units that form on the substrate and then act as suitable sites for the subsequent diamond thin film growth. Diamond nucleation affects not only the final grain sizes but also diamond thin film thickness, homogeneity, morphology, defects, surface roughness, and adhesion. Over the years, different diamond nucleation methods have been developed.

Scratching substrate surface with an abrasive powder has been the most commonly used method. Diamond nucleation can be enhanced by scratching the substrate surface with diamond [39], SiC [40], cubic-BN [41], Cu or stainless steel [42], ZrB2 [43], Al2O3 [44], etc.; abrasive powders among which diamond powder has been the most effective one. Scratching works for most of the substrates. For Si substrates, nucleation densities in the range from 107 to 108 cm−2 could be routinely obtained by scratching with diamond powder against a meager 104 cm−2 on unscratched Si substrates. Nucleation density depends on scratching time and grit size of the diamond powder. Final diamond morphology changes from large isolated crystals for short scratching times to small but high-density crystals for long scratching times [45]. Grit size of 0.25 µm is the most effective for manual scratching [46], while 40–50 µm grit is good for scratching the substrate surface in an ultrasonic bath using a grit suspension [47]. Scratching leaves diamond residue in the scratched grooves that acts as seeds for the subsequent diamond growth [48]. In addition, scratching changes the surface morphology. It creates edges, steps, dislocations, and other surface defective sites which are chemically active; diamond-forming gas species show a great affinity to get adsorbed on these sites [43, 44, 49, 50].

Unscratched Si surfaces that have undergone either HF/HNO3 etching [44] or Si+ implantation treatment [51] have also shown enhanced diamond nucleation. However, creation of etch pits on unscratched Si surfaces using acid, H+ [52], or other reactive gas treatments [42] did not result in improved diamond nucleation. Similarly, generation of defect sites via implantation with surface saturation levels of C+ [53] or Ar+ [52] on the unscratched substrates did not result in nucleation enhancement. Coating the substrate surface with graphite [54, 55], amorphous carbon [54, 56], diamond-like carbon [57–59], C60, and mechanical oil [56] has also been employed to enhance diamond nucleation.

Bias-enhanced nucleation (BEN) is another method which not only results in higher nucleation densities but also in oriented or epitaxial nucleation. In this method, a negative bias voltage is generally applied on the substrate in a typical MWCVD setup [60, 61]; nucleation densities as high as 1010 to 1011 cm−2 on mirror-polished Si substrates can be achieved [61]. Using this method, hetero-epitaxial growth of diamond on silicon [62, 63] and silicon carbide substrates [64] was achieved, respectively. BEN mechanism was explained by suggesting a shallow ion-implantation model in which the sp3 bonded carbon clusters, formed by low-energy ion-implantation act as the active nucleation sites [65, 66]. On the other hand, it was indicated that the critical step for the nucleation should be the formation of a surface carbide layer and increase in atomic hydrogen concentration due to substrate biasing [67]. In addition toabove-discussed surface defects serving as the nucleation sites, the enhanced surface diffusion [68,69] and sticking probability of carbon on silicon due to ion bombardment have been identified as the decisive factors. BEN in HFCVD system yields a nucleation density of 109 to 1010 cm−2 on mirror-polished Si [70] which is similar to the result obtained in the MWCVD system.

High diamond nucleation densities (109 to 1011 cm−2) can be also obtained on mirror-polished Si substrates using either HFCVD or ECR microwave plasma CVD system working at very low pressures (0.1–1 Torr) [71]. In order to obtain high diamond nucleation densities, the substrate surface must be in such a way that: (a) surface adsorption sites can be created for the impinging diamond-forming gas species, and (b) the distributed region of adsorption sites is larger than the nuclei size for the subsequent crystal growth. This effect was also found in the case of diamond growth on porous silicon [72]. More recently, nucleation densities in the range from 1012 to 1014 cm−2 were obtained using a ring-type positive bias setup near the substrate [73]. sec.title: 3.2 Growth
sec.p: The following have been used to explain diamond growth: (a) C3+ cations or positively charged reaction surface influences {1 1 1} diamond growth [74, 75]; however, under HFCVD conditions, this fails since C3+ cations are scant and the substrate surface is uncharged, (b) methyl radicals are the dominant species for {1 1 1}, {1 0 0}, and {1 1 0} diamond growth under HFCVD conditions [76], (c) methyl or methane is more effective than acetylene for diamond film growth [77, 78], (d) nine-carbon model compound (bicyclononane) based diamond growth involving only neutral CH3 and hydrogen atoms [79], (e) acetylene is present in greater quantities than CH3 under HFCVD conditions and therefore, it is the primary growth specie for {1 1 1} diamond and other low index surfaces [80–86], and (f) the primary growth specie for nanocrystalline diamond growth is C2 dimer but not CH3 or C2H2 [87, 88].

Crystal morphology is determined by the appearance of facets, which have the slowest growth rate along their normal and by the corresponding relative growth rates [89]. Based on certain controlled experiments, the regularity of the appearance of the diamond facets is now possible to explain [90–93]. The growth rate of (1 0 0) facet depends on the concentration of CH2 or CH3, while that of (1 1 1) facet relies on both CH3 and C2H2 concentrations. If CH3 concentration near the substrate is much higher than C2H2 concentration, {1 0 0} growth rate will be high; the crystal appears to have just {1 1 1} diamond faces. In contrast, if the C2H2 concentration near the growth surface is dominant, the {1 1 1} diamond face grows faster, which consequently results in the appearance of {1 0 0} diamond facets. In most cases, CH3 and C2H2 concentrations are comparable resulting in the presence of both {1 0 0} and {1 1 1} facets.

The stable nano-sized crystals formed during the nucleation stage typically exhibit spherical shapes. With time, nucleation density increases up to a certain value upon which it terminates or ceases to occur at a measurable rate. The isolated crystallites now grow and develop facets and they grow large enough to coalesce with one another; they form grain boundaries and then continue to grow as a continuous film. The morphology of a growing diamond surface depends on the grow rates of different diamond facets. Diamond film morphology assessment is made by the growth parameter α=3ν100/ν111, where ν100 and ν111 are the growth velocities normal to (1 0 0) and (1 1 1) diamond facets, respectively [89, 94]. The grains exhibiting the fastest growth in the direction perpendicular to the substrate overshadow other slower growing grains to form a continuous film with a columnar structure [95]. This mode of film growth is known as evolutionary selection principle [96]. On the contrary, an oriented diamond growth dependent on facet reactivity and selectivity is also possible [97]. To explain this novel growth mechanism, the energy levels of the frontier molecular orbitals (FMOs) and other nearby orbitals of CH3, diamond nanoparticle, and SiH3 were determined (Fig. 3). By judging the energy difference between the FMOs of the diamond and CH3/SiH3, it was found that {1 1 1} diamond facets are more reactive with SiH3, readily allowing the formation of SiC phases on them, while leaving the {1 0 0} facet clean and with only diamond growth. The selection of diamond (0 0 1) plane growth is therefore due to the distortion and/or termination of non-{0 0 1} plane growth. Here, the evolutionary selection theory [89, 96] is no more valid because the growth of all the non-{0 0 1} faces is interrupted due to the nano-β-SiC deposition, even though their growth rates could be higher than that of (0 0 1) face. The formation of [0 0 1] texture is therefore due to an angular selection. Fig. 3
The energy levels of FMOs (with isosurfaces as inset) and other nearby orbitals of the reactants of CH3, diamond nanoparticles (C54H56), and SiH3. The two energy levels with equal value next to the HOMO for CH3 or SiH3 are degenerate. Reprinted with permission [97]

Diamond growth models are developed by considering the effects of C1 hydrocarbon species, namely CH3, CH2, CH, and C on both monoradical and biradical reaction surface sites [98]. At typical diamond CVD conditions, diamond growth takes place mainly via the addition of CH3 species to monoradical sites. Growth can also take place via the addition of CH3 species to the biradical sites; here, the unused surface dangling bonds can be rapidly hydrogenated during the conversion of CH3 adducts into a CH2 surface groups [99]. At some deposition conditions, thebiradical mechanism is dominant; in this case, theprobability of species such as C2 and C2H to be the biradical site adducts is enhanced. Such reactive species then have the opportunity to cross-link on the surface, creating a strongly bonded and non-etchable defect. This surface defect could act as either a nucleation point for the growth of a new epitaxial layer, or, if it is misaligned with the existing lattice, for the growth of a new crystallite in a different direction. The latter possibility is often termed as ‘renucleation’, and leads to a decrease in the average crystal size. If renucleation occurs frequently, the crystallite size can drop from millimetre to micrometre, and eventually to nanometre, and the films are termed single-crystalline diamond, microcrystalline diamond, and (ultra)-nanocrystalline diamond accordingly. In addition to CH3, addition of the other less abundant but highly reactive C1 species, particularly, atomic C, to either type of radical sites at high H atom concentration, can also be a route to diamond growth, since the dangling bonds on the adduct would be readily hydrogenated, converting the adduct into CH2. However, at low H atom concentration, the dangling bonds on the adduct can cross-link to lattice sites, again leading to renucleation and subsequent smaller crystal sizes. Models based on the surface migration of reactive species could predict even diamond growth rates and average crystallite sizes [100, 101]. May et al. [102] have critically reviewed the diamond growth mechanism to simulate diamond growth on the (1 0 0) surface and presented a unified model for diamond growth based on Monte Carlo simulations.

The most crucial aspect in a typical diamond CVD process is that the hydrocarbon gas must be diluted in hydrogen to as low as 1 per cent and that the hydrogen must be dissociated into atomic hydrogen which has several specific roles. During the deposition process, atomic hydrogen etches graphite about 20–30 times faster than diamond, resulting in rapid removal of graphite and other non-diamond phases from the substrate and thereby allowing only clusters with diamond structure to remain and grow [93]. It stabilizes the diamond surface and maintains the sp3 hybridization configuration [103]. Atomic hydrogen not only converts hydrocarbons into respective radicals, which are the necessary species for diamond formation but also abstracts hydrogen from the hydrocarbons attached on the surface [104], thereby creating active sites for adsorption of the diamond-forming species. Presence of excess atomic hydrogen than required causes severe abstraction reactions resultingin the formation of more mono-hydrogenated dimers, which in turn will result in the formation of graphite. Diamond growth is therefore a result of concurrently occurring processes, namely diamond deposition and graphite etching. The growth of diamond occurs if the deposition rate is larger than the graphite etching rate. During CVD growth of diamond films, both atomic H and H+ ions in the plasma cause etching, and H+ ions etch even faster than atomic H [105–108].

Oxygen (in the form of CO, O2, or alcohol) to the CVD reaction gases has not only a beneficial effect on the growth rate and quality of the diamond films but also allows low-temperature diamond growth [109]. It was found that oxygen has only a minor effect on the mole fractions of radical species such as H and CH3 [110]. Also, OH is formed at concentrations sufficient for the removal of non-diamond carbon at a rate comparable to that of diamond growth. At low temperatures (<800°C), the addition of oxygen not only enhances the growth rate but also extends the region of diamond formation [111]. At temperatures lower than 500°C, oxygen was explained to have stronger preferential etching behaviour than hydrogen. Atomic oxygen presence also helps in effective abstraction of surface hydrogen [112], which balances strongly the abstraction of surface hydrogen. However, presence of excess oxygen than required will cause strong hydrogen abstractions and even oxidation of the growing surface. OH, O, O2, F, and F2 species are found to be better graphite etchants than atomic hydrogen. Based on this, it was shown that pyrolysis of fluorocarbons such as tetrafluoromethane (CF4) could lead to epitaxial diamond grain growth [113]. In another development, hydrogen-deficient carbon-containing noble gas plasma was used to obtain phase-pure nanocrystalline diamond thin films [114].

sec.title: 4.1 Epitaxial
sec.p:
Fabrication of diamond-based electronic devices requires diamond single crystal or epitaxial films. Even though epitaxial diamond films can be grown on natural or high-pressure high temperature (HPHT) diamond [115–122], their industrial viability (high costs and too small HPHT diamonds for applications, etc.) is poor. To counter such problems, synthesis of hetero-epitaxial diamond thin films on cubic boron nitride (cubic-BN) [123–130], Si [62, 63, 70, 131–138], β-SiC [64, 139], BeO [140], Ni [141], Pt [142], Co [143], Ir [144–146], and SrTiO3 [147] substrates has been now made possible. High-resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM) lattice image of diamond (0 0 1) on silicon (001) is shown in Fig. 4. This epitaxial film was prepared using MWCVD by carefully controlling the nucleation step (BEN process); diamond nucleation with more than90 per cent [0 0 1]-oriented nuclei were achieved [69]. High-density nucleation and highly oriented diamond films were also synthesized by applying a negative bias to the substrate in a HFCVD system [68, 148]. A possible mechanism for the loss of diamond epitaxy was also suggested [149, 150]. Early epitaxial diamond film studies indicated that the growth of diamond on Si occurs via β-SiC interlayer [151, 152]; however, a direct lattice observation of the interface between silicon and epitaxially grown diamond crystal has proven it wrong [132, 133]. Theoretical investigations of the interface structure between diamond and silicon have also provided support for the epitaxial growth of diamond on silicon [153, 154]. Fig. 4
HRTEM cross-sectional lattice image showing epitaxially grown diamond on Si; the image is taken along the [1 1 0] direction of the diamond–silicon interface. Reprinted with permission [131]

sec.title: 4.2 Nanodiamond
sec.p:
Nanodiamond thin films fall in the category of nanocrystalline (NC) films that possess unusual structure, properties, and applications [155]. These thin films possess high uniformity, extremely high grain boundary density, and pin-hole free ultrasmooth surface morphology even for film thicknesses well below 1 µm. Nanodiamond films were first synthesized from a hydrogen-deficient carbon-containing noble gas CVD plasma [114]; NC diamond films can also be synthesized by adding nitrogen [87] to a high methane-containing CVD plasma or a very little amount of tetramethylsilane (TMS) [156] to a very low methane-containing CVD plasma. A plane view transmission electron microscope image (along with the electron diffraction pattern) of a nanodiamond film synthesized by adding TMS to CH4 and H2 gas mixture is shown in Fig. 5. Fig. 5
HRTEM plane view image of a nanodiamond film

Ion-bombardment-induced high-frequency secondary diamond nucleation also leads to NC diamond film formation [157, 158]. Owing to the shallow ion penetration into the subsurface region (ion subplantation) [159], the sp3 bonded carbon clusters are formed which act as the nucleation precursors. The negative bias applied to the substrate causes the positively charged ions in the CVD reactor to accelerate towards the substrate’s surface and bombard it, thereby removing the contamination and facilitating cluster formation at the surface. Itwas demonstrated [106, 150] that via H+ ion bombardment during the diamond CVD, variable diamond film growth from microcrystalline (MC), through a fine crystalline and fully (0 0 1) textured film morphology, to a NC diamond growth is possible independent of the substrate type.

sec.title: 4.3 Diamond nanocomposite films
sec.p: Both CVD and non-CVD methods have been used tosynthesize diamond composites [160–167] with: (a)carbides of molybdenum, tungsten, and titanium, (b) nitrides of silicon, aluminium, and titanium, (c)nickel alloy, and (d) copper–titanium–gold alloy. These are not phase mixture diamond nanocomposite films. In the recent past, a special class of diamond composite films, namely a-C/nanodiamond composite films synthesized via CVD techniques have gained a lot of prominence [168–170].

On the other hand, there are phase mixture diamond nanocomposite systems such as diamond/TiC [171], diamond/WC [172], and diamond/β-SiC [173–175]. The idea behind synthesis of nanocrystalline phase mixture composite films is to obtain films those possess a whole range of combined properties of diamond and the other phases (TiC, WC, β-SiC, etc.). Field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) surface morphology image of a diamond/β-SiC nanocomposite thin film is shown in Fig. 6. This particular film system has recently gained a lot of importance in biosensing-related studies [176]. Fig. 6
Ultrahigh magnification FE scanning electron plane view micrograph of a phase mixture diamond/β-SiC nanocomposite film deposited (using the setup shown in Fig. 1) on a bias-enhanced nucleated (1 0 0) Si substrate. Bright and dark regions represent diamond and β-SiC, respectively

sec.title: 4.4 Doped diamond thin films
sec.p: Diamond thin film-based semiconductor device fabrication depends greatly on the development of conductive diamond thin films. Owing to the great efforts of researchers worldwide, it is now possible to synthesize doped (both p and n) diamond thin films [177–184]. The conductive nature of diamond thin films can be varied from semiconducting through metallic to even superconducting using annealing, doping, and ion-implantation methodologies.

Annealing diamond thin films under vacuum at high temperatures results in the formation of non-diamond conductive carbon phase along the grain boundaries and structural defects in the diamond film bulk, which in turn results in p-type semiconduction [185]. Surface and subsurface (~nm) of hydrogen-terminated diamond thin films can be made p-type semiconductive typically by physisorption of surface adsorbates such as solvated ionic species or neutral species with high electron affinity. Solvated ionic species apparently extract electrons from the valence band of diamond and react electrochemically, while the neutral species reduce the ionization potential of the diamond surface and makes its electron affinity apparently negative, which in turn leads to an exchange of electrons between the valence band and the adsorbates. This type of conduction is hole-mediated and the process is known as surface transfer doping [186, 187]. Diamond thin films can also be made conductive by substitutional doping; hetero-atoms like B, Al, N, P, S, Si, Ni, As, Sb, Cr, Ni, Fe, W, Mo, etc., can substitute some of the sp3 carbon atoms in the diamond lattice, leading to the formation of new energy levels in the energy band of diamond that facilitate p- and n-type conductions depending on the type of dopant. p-Type dopant (B,Al, etc.) results in the formation of discrete acceptor levels (which are accessible to valence band electrons) above the valence band of diamond. When electrons are promoted into these levels, delocalized holes are generated in the valence band which facilitate the p-type conductance. n-Type dopant (N, P, etc.) results in the formation of a donor level whose electrons can be easily excited into the nearby conduction band. Doped diamond thin films are mainly obtained by: (a) in situ and (b) ex situ doping routes. In situ doping involves gas phase manipulation, i.e. addition of certain amount of dopant-containing gas species to the diamond-forming gas mixtures during the diamond thin film synthesis. Ex situ doping involves doping into the already synthesized diamond thin films, mainly ion-implantation. The closely packed diamond lattice makes substitutional doping, a challenging task. Some of the above-mentioned dopants can be incorporated into the lattice during the synthesis of diamond thin films, while some can be incorporated via ion-implantation [188–190]. Doping via ion-implantation involves forcing the dopant ions into the subsurface regions of diamond thin films rendering them semiconductive. During ion-implantation, since the dopant ion energy is greater than the binding energy of the sp3 carbon atoms, not only severe damage takes place in the diamond thin films but there is also a possibility of disturbing the stability of the metastable sp3 bonds, leading to the formation of stable sp2 graphitic bonds upon subsequent high-temperature annealing that is carried out to annihilate the damages. It has also been pointed out that doping via ion-implantation leads to the formation of resistive diamond thin films, probably due to the compensation (of the desired electrical activity of the dopants) arising from damage-related centres forming in between acceptor and donor energy levels [191]. Among the available doped diamond thin films, the p-type boron-doped diamond thin films have been extensively studied [192].

sec.title: 5 MOST RECENT DEVELOPMENTS
sec.p: During the past 5 years, noticeable developments in diamond thin film synthesis have taken place. Interesting diamond thin film deposition techniques such as pulsed liquid injection (PLI) CVD [193], hot wire CVD [194], and surface wave plasma CVD [195] have been used. PLICVD involves flash evaporation ofsmall doses of organic compounds (acetone, ethanol, and methanol mixtures) in an evaporation zone (~280°C), subsequent transport of the resulting vapour mixture by a carrier gas into a high-temperature zone (~850°C), and the diamond deposition onto the substrates in the high-temperature zone. Surface wave-excited plasma in a MWCVD reactor enables low-temperature and large-area diamond thin film deposition possible.

Effective diamond nucleation methodologies are now available [73, 195–197]. A dome-shaped Mo anode was used during BEN of diamond under typical diamond growth conditions in MWCVD [195]. The shape of the anode resulted in uniform diamond nucleation on the whole substrate surface. This has also reduced the time consumption in diamond thin film synthesis. In another development, BEN of diamond was implemented in a MWCVD reactor by applying RF power to the substrate holder [196]. This arrangement has created a RF plasma (inducing DC self-bias) very close to the substrate surface, resulting in effective acceleration of diamond-forming species towards the substrate. Another interesting development is the novel nucleation process (NNP), [197] which is a combination of carbon layer formation under diamond growth conditions (using only carbon gas source) and typical ultrasonic seeding. In the initial stages of NNP, lateral diamond growth takes place until the initial grains coalesce; thereafter, columnar growth takes place. NNP might help in the development of diamond composite films since NPP helps in the deposition of diamond as encapsulation layers.

Deposition of diamond thin films onto several important substrate materials such as hard metal [198], titanium [199], titanium alloys [200, 201], titanium nitride [201], cubic boron nitride [201], molybdenum [202], polyimide [202], gallium nitride [203], and quartz [204] has been reported. It is evident that diamond thin film synthesis at low temperatures has become prominent [195, 201–204]. High growth rate [205–207] and ultrananocrystalline [208, 209] diamond thin film depositions have also been greatly developed.

sec.title: 6 CONCLUSIONS
sec.p: Diamond thin film synthesis (via CVD routes) is now a well-understood and controllable process. At present, CVD techniques such as HFCVD, MWCVD, RF-PCVD, DC-PCVD, ECR-MWCVD, and combustion flame-CVD and their hybrids are in use. It is now possible to theoretically explain as well as predict diamond growth and experimentally control CVD diamond synthesis processes to obtain diamond thin films with desired properties. Microcrystalline (poly), highly oriented, epitaxial, nano, and nanocomposite diamond thin films can now be routinely synthesized on a wide range of substrates.
